Description: Scarab carved from cream-coloured steatite; back relatively well-defined with simply marked head and clypeus, prothorax and elytra indicated by fine incisions; V-incisions on elytra at junction with prothorax on each side; at side, well-shaped legs; underside incised with motif arranged vertically consisting of an oval surrounding the name of Menkheperra, surmounted by two ostrich feathers and flanked by a pair of cobras on both sides; base of the oval flanked by Maat feathers associated with simplified cobras, one wearing the white crown to right, the other the red crown to left; neb-basket sign underneath completing the composition; longitudinally pierced.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This scarab was published several times by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 189; Petrie 1889, pl. 61, no. 1956; Petrie 1917, pl. LIII, type 25 C.13, cat. no. M.35). The complex composition depicted on the underside can be related to some Menkheperra scarabs analysed by B. Jaeger, though none is a direct parallel (see especially the composition with uraei in Jaeger 1982, § 447, 450, 452 and fig. 213a). Jaeger, B. 1982. Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W.M.F. 1889, Historical scarabs: a series of drawings from the principal collections arranged chronologically, London. Petrie, W.M.F. 1917, Scarabs and cylinders with names (British School of Archaeology in Egypt 29), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 189)
